children.name: criticize b2
children.definition: criticize/criticiseuk  to express your disapproval of someone or something, or to talk about their faultsopp praise: phê phán chỉ trích
examples: ron does nothing but criticize and complain all the time.
be strongly/sharply/heavily criticized
the decision has been strongly criticized by teachers.
the new law has beenwidely criticized.
criticize sb/sth for (doing) sth
he has been criticized for incompetence.
doctors have criticized the government for failing to invest enough in the health service.
criticize sb/sth as sth
the report has been criticized as inaccurate and incomplete.
strongly/severely/heavily criticize somebody/somethingpublic transport has been severely criticized in the report.
sharply/harshly/fiercely criticize somebody/something(= in an angry way )his attorney sharply criticized the police yesterday.
be widely criticizedthe proposal was widely criticized.
publicly criticize somebody/somethingthe head coach publicly criticized the referee’s decision.
roundly criticize somebody/something(= strongly and severely )their research has been roundly criticized.
openly criticize somebody/something(= in a public and direct way )they openly criticized the government’s handling of the crisis.
repeatedly/frequently/constantly criticizethe fashion industry is frequently criticized for presenting extremely thin models as beautiful.
be quick to criticize sb/sthsome groups were quick to criticize the president.
criticize sb/sth on the grounds that(= for the reason that )the survey was criticized on the grounds that the sample was too small.

children.name: be critical b2
children.definition: be critical to strongly criticize a plan, system, or way of doing sth, especially when you givedetailedreasonswhy you think it is wrong: chỉ trích , chê bai
examples: don’t be so critical - we’re doing our best.
be critical of
miller was critical of the way the company was managed.
many economists are critical of the government’s economic policies.
be highly/ strongly criticalvery critical
environmental groups were highly critical of the government’s new transportation policy.
many parents are strongly critical of the school.
he made some highly critical remarks.

children.name: be a critic of c1
children.definition: be a critic of sb/sth if sb is a critic of the government, a person in authority etc, they regularly and publicly criticize them, especially by giving detailed reasons for this: là nhà phê bình ai đó/cái gì đó
examples: ▪ she is one of the most well-known critics of the american private school system.
be an outspoken critic of sb/sthnot afraid to critize strongly and publicly
▪ he is regarded as one of congress’s most outspoken critics of television violence.
be somebody’s greatest/biggest etccritic criticize them more than anyone else does
▪ mr levy has established a reputation as the committee’s biggest, most vehement critic.

children.name: sth you say or write to criticize
criticism b2
children.definition: criticism what you say or write when you criticize sb or sthopp praise: sự phê bình chỉ trích, lời bình phẩm trỉ trích
examples: bill’s very sensitive to any kind of criticism.
criticism of
the report makes many criticisms of the nation’s prison system.
my main criticism of the scheme is that it does nothing to help families on low incomes.
strong/severe/heavy criticismthis decision attracted heavy criticism from environmental groups.
fierce/bitter/harsh/sharp criticism(= involving angry feelings )the prison system has been the object of fierce criticism.
public criticismas a politician, you have to get used to public criticism.
constructive criticism(= aimed at improving something or someone in a helpful way )praise and constructive criticism are both very useful.
widespread criticismthere was widespread criticism of his speech.
growing/mounting criticismthe government was faced with mounting criticism at home and abroad.
outspoken criticism(= said very openly and directly )i was surprised by his outspoken criticism of the system.
implied criticism(= suggested indirectly, rather than said openly )she sensed the implied criticism in his remarks.
draw/attract/provoke criticism(= be criticized )the plan has drawn criticism from some groups.
come under criticism/come in for criticism(= be criticized )the deal came under fierce criticism from other american airlines.
meet (with) criticism(= be criticized )his theory met with harsh criticism from colleagues.
face criticismhe has often faced criticism in the local press.
accept/take criticism(= allow it and learn from it )very few people know how to accept criticism.
level criticism at somebody/something(= aim it at someone or something )a great deal of criticism was levelled at the company.
single somebody out for criticism(= to criticize one person, organization etc specifically )the goalkeeper was singled out for criticism.
be the subject of criticism/be subjected to criticism(= be criticized by people )the club has been the subject of criticism since last october.
be open to criticism(= be willing or able to accept it )management have decided this and i don't think they're open to criticism.
be sensitive to criticism(= to react to criticism, often in a bad way )he was highly sensitive to criticism in the press.
a storm/barrage of criticism(= a lot of criticism )his comments provoked a barrage of criticism.

children.name: attack c2
children.definition: attack a statement that criticizes sb publicly, especially in politics or business: công kích , trỉ trích
examples: attack on
the magazine recently published a viciouspersonal attackon the novelist.
o'brien promised to continue his attacks on the film industry.
come under attackbe criticized by sb
once again the oil companies have come under attack from environmentalists.
the company has come under fierce attack for its decision to close the factory.
launch an attack
france launched a bitter attack on eu proposals to reduce farm subsidies.
go on the attack(= start to criticize sb severely )

children.name: slur x
children.definition: slur an unfair criticism that is intended to make people dislike sb or sth: gièm pha, nói xấu,
examples: your accusation of bribe-taking is a slur which i shall never forgive.
a racist slur
slur on/against
milton regarded her comment as a slur on his country.
how dare shecastaslur on(= criticize )my character?

children.name: put-down x
children.definition: put-down spoken informal sth that sb says to sb, especially when other people are there, that criticizes them and makes them feel stupid or unimportant: làm nhục, làm bẽ mặt
examples: ▪ she was a master of the sarcastic put-down
.▪ i didn’t mean it as a put-down but i could tell from her response that she took my criticism personally.

children.name: critic c1
children.definition: critic sb who criticizes sb or sth especially in public:người trỉ trích
examples: the prime minister answered his critics in a televised speech.
critic of
daley accused critics of the city’s police department of lying.
critics of the scheme have said that it will not solve the problem of teenage crime.
fierce/outspoken critic
an outspoken critic of the government

children.name: find fault with c2
children.definition: find fault with to criticize things that are wrong with someone or something, especiallysmallandunimportantthings: bắt bẻ, kiếm truyện
examples: no-one enjoys working for a boss who always finds fault with their work.
find fault with sb for sth
the report found fault with the police department for its handling of the case.

children.name: pick holes in x
children.definition: pick holes in especially british,informalto criticizesmalldetails in someone’s ideas or plans - use this about someone who seems to bedeliberatelylooking for problems and mistakes: tìm ra được lỗ hổng, đào bới
examples: as soon as she stopped talking, janet’s colleagues began to pick holes in the idea.

children.name: knock x
children.definition: knock to criticize sb, their work, or their performance in an unfair and annoying way: chỉ trích gay gắt, phê bình kịch liệt, “đánh đập”
examples: it’s hard to knock gordon because he always works so hard.
critics knocked his latest film for its portrayal of women.
don’t knock it!
hey, don’t knock it! it’s the only suit i’ve got!

children.name: put down u
children.definition: put down to make sb feel unimportant or stupid especially by criticizing them in public: làm bẽ mặt, làm nhục
examples: television programs always seem to put down people from the south.
she enjoys putting me down in front of other people.

children.name: slag off x
children.definition: slag off uk informal to criticize sb, especially in a nasty and unfair way: vu khống, phỉ báng
examples: she spent the whole evening slagging off her ex-boyfriend.
when the team isn’t winning everyone starts slagging them off.
he’s always slagging you off behind your back.

children.name: bitch about x
children.definition: bitch aboutsb informal to make nasty remarks about sb when that person is not there: nói xấu, vu khống
examples: people in our office are always bitching about each other.

children.name: get at x
children.definition: get at sb informal to keep criticizing sb by making remarks about their behaviour or habits, especially in an unkind or annoying way: chế nhạo, giễu cợt
examples: ▪ i try not to take it personally -- he gets at everyone on the team.
get at sb about
▪ my mother keeps getting at me about the state of my room.

children.name: nitpicking
children.definition: informal the annoying habit of criticizing sb about unimportant details, especially in sb’s work: soi mói, bới lông tìm vết
examples: i’ve had enough of your constant nit-picking. why can’t you say something encouraging?
nitpicking[attri]
nitpicking remarks

children.name: scathing x
children.definition: scathing criticizing sb or sth verystrongly, because you think they are completelywrongor of verylowquality: cay độc , gay gắt
examples: scathing attack/remark/comment etc
a scathing attack on the government’s planned tax increases
her new book is a scathing attack on american imperialism in central america.
the health department issued a scathing report on conditions in local hospitals.
scathing about
‘the new york times’ was particularly scathing about his performance.
he’s always been so scathing about psychiatrists.

children.name: pejorative x
children.definition: pejorative formal a pejorative word expresses disapproval, often in an offensive way: miệt thị
examples: he used the word ‘girl’ in the pejorative sense when referring to the women who worked for him.
for hard-line republicans, the word ‘liberal’ had become a pejorative term.
pejoratively[adv]
the word ‘liberal’ seems to be used prejoratively by both the left and the right.

children.name: derogatory x
children.definition: derogatory a derogatory remark expresses disapproval of sth or sb and is often also insulting: xúc phạm, hạ thấp người khác
examples: i wish you wouldn’t make derogatory remarks about members of my family.
i didn’t like the way he made derogatory comments about his colleagues.

children.name: critical b2
children.definition: critical/ˈkrɪtɪkəl/  a critical statement, report, or description criticizes someone or something: chỉ trích, chê bai
examples: ▪ critical remarks by a teacher can damage the confidence of children.
highly criticalvery critical
▪ the government has just published a highly critical report on the state of the education system.

children.name: negative b2
children.definition: negative a negative comment, report etc is intended to criticize someone or something, especially in a way that is unnecessary or unfair; a negative person has a tendency to criticize or complain about everything, especially when this is annoying or unfair: tiêu cực
examples: ▪ the portrayal of working women in the media tends to be very negative.
▪ you shouldn’t let his negative comments get you down - he doesn’t know what he’s talking about.
▪ i wish you’d stop being so negative all the time!

children.name: attack c1
children.definition: attackto criticize sb or sth very strongly, especially publicly in the newspapers, on tv etc: chỉ trích , phê phán , tấn công
examples: ▪ several actors have attacked proposals to cut the theatre’s budget.
attack sb for (doing) sth
▪ union leaders attacked management for eliminating employee health benefits.

children.name: slam x
children.definition: slam to criticize sb or sth very strongly in a public statement -- used especially in newspapers: đả kích, "đóng sầm"
examples: ▪ sullivan never misses a chance to slam the tobacco industry.
slam sb for doing sth
▪ police slammed drivers for ignoring safety warnings

children.name: pan x
children.definition: pan informal to strongly criticize sth such as a film, play, or a performance by writing about it in a newspaper, talking about it on television etc: chỉ trích gay gắt
examples: the movie was panned by all the critics.
her first movie was panned by the critics.

children.name: tear sb to shreds x
children.definition: tear sb/sth to shreds to find a lot of faults in sb’s ideas or arguments and criticize them very severely: đả kích tơi tả
examples: the prosecution will tear him to shreds.
after the prosecutor had presented his case, the defence lawyer tore his arguments to shreds.

children.name: pillory x
children.definition: pillory bêu rếu, “đem gông, bỏ gông”
examples: be pilloriedespecially writtento be strongly criticized by a lot of people in the newspapers, on tv etc :
he was pilloried in the right-wing press.
harper was pilloried in the press after his team’s sixth consecutive defeat.
middleton suffered the ultimate humiliation of being pilloried by his colleagues in front of the television cameras.

children.name: do a hatchet job on x
children.definition: do a hatchet job on informal to criticize every part of sb’s character or work: bôi nhọ, bêu rếu, “cái rìu nhỏ”
examples: ▪ field did a complete hatchet job on his former colleague at a cabinet meeting last week.

children.name: lay into x
children.definition: lay intosb/tear intosb informal to criticize sb very strongly for sth they have done,especially by shouting at them :quở trách, chỉ trích, đánh tới tấp
examples: the teacher really laid into us this morning - told us we’d all fail if we didn’t start doing some work.
he started laying into one of his staff for being late.
lay into about
you should have heard my wife laying into me about coming home late last night.

children.name: come in for criticism c2
children.definition: come in for criticism bị chỉ trích
examples: the unions came in for strong criticism from the government after the strike.
caro came in for a lot of criticism for his biography of the late president.
the director has come in for a lot of criticism over his handling of the affair.

children.name: be under attack b2
children.definition: be under attack/fire to be severely criticized, especially in public: bị chỉ trích, bị bêu rếu
examples: banks are under attack for their refusal to reduce interest rates on loans to small businesses.
come under attack/fire
his theories came under attack from other scientists.
the police department has come under fire for the recent rise in violent crime.

children.name: take a lot of flak x
children.definition: get/take a lot of flak informal to be criticized a lot for sth: “hỏa lực phòng không” bị la mắng, bị đả kích
examples: ferguson been getting a lot of flak for the team’s poor performance recently.
the immigration department is taking a lot of political flak for not moving faster to help the refugees.
lilley hastakena lot offlakfor his views on drugs.

children.name: be open to criticism b2
children.definition: be open to criticism if sb or sth is open to criticism, there are good reasons for criticizing them: có thể bị chỉ trích
examples: the general is open to criticism for his handling of the war.
current reforms in the legal system may be open to criticism if they appear to be undemocratic.

children.name: be in the firing line x
children.definition: be in the firing lineuk/ on the firing lineus  likely to be criticized for sth, even if you are not the only person who is responsible for it: đứng mũi chịu sào
examples: as head of the police department, hall is constantly on the firing line.
when you’re in the firing line, it’s tempting to avoid making difficult decisions.

children.name: target c1
children.definition: target/ˈtɑːʳgɪt, ˈtɑːʳgət/  an organization, person in authority etc that is criticized, especially by a lot of people: mục tiêu chỉ trích
examples: target of
kay was the target of a noisy demonstration in which 54 people were arrested.
target for
the communist party has become the main target for critical attack among left-wing intellectuals.
